content.html:
Students will complete the following questions to practice the skills they have learned in this lesson.

  1. Select two true statements about the graph that represents \(y=2x(x-11)\).
    • Its \(x\)-intercepts are at \((-2,0)\) and \((11,0)\).
    • Its \(x\)-intercepts are at \((0,0)\) and \((11,0)\).
    • Its \(x\)-intercepts are at \((2,0)\) and \((-11,0)\).
    • It has only one \(x\)-intercept.
    • The \(x\)-coordinate of its vertex is -4.5.
    • The \(x\)-coordinate of its vertex is 11.
    • The \(x\)-coordinate of its vertex is 4.5.
    • The \(x\)-coordinate of its vertex is 5.5.

ANSWER: Its \(x\)-intercepts are at \((0,0)\) and \((11,0)\). The \(x\)-coordinate of its vertex is 5.5.

  1. Select two equations whose graphs have a vertex with \(x\)-coordinate 2.
    • \(y=(x-2)(x-4)\)
    • \(y=(x-2)(x+2)\)
    • \(y=(x-1)(x-3)\)
    • \(y=x(x+4)\)
    • \( y=x(x-4)\)

ANSWER: \(y=(x-1)(x-3)\), \(y=x(x-4)\)

  1. Three different equations are given. Refer to these equations to complete questions a–f.

Equation

\(x\)-intercepts

\(x\)-coordinate of the vertex

\(y=x(x-2)\)

a. _____

b. _____

\(y=(x-4)(x+5)\)

c. _____

d. _____

\(y=-5x(3-x)\)

e. _____

f. _____

    1. What are the \(x\)-intercepts of the graph that represents \(y=x(x-2)\)?
      • \((0,0)\) and \((0, 2)\)
      • \((0,0)\) and \((2, 0)\)
      • \((0,0)\) and \((0,-2)\)
      • \((0,0)\) and \((-2,0)\)

ANSWER: \((0,0)\) and \((2,0)\)

    1. What is the \(x\)-coordinate of the vertex of the graph that represents \(y=x(x-2)\)? 

ANSWER: 1

    1. What are the \(x\)-intercepts of the graph that represents \(y=(x-4)(x+5)\)?
      • \((-5,0)\) and \((4,0)\)
      • \((0,-5)\) and \((0,4)\)
      • \((5,0)\) and \((-4,0)\)
      • \((0,5)\) and \((0,-4)\)

ANSWER: \((-5,0)\) and \((4,0)\)

    1. What is the \(x\)-coordinate of the vertex of the graph that represents \(y=(x-4)(x+5)\)?

ANSWER: -0.5

    1. What are the \(x\)-intercepts of the graph that represents \(y=-5x(3-x)\)?
      • \((0,0)\) and \((0,-3)\)
      • \((0,0)\) and \((-3,0)\)
      • \((0,0)\) and \((3,0)\)
      • \((0,0)\) and \((0,3)\)

ANSWER: \((0,0)\) and \((3,0)\)

    1. What is the \(x\)-coordinate of the vertex of the graph that represents \(y=-5x(3-x)\)?

ANSWER: 1.5

  1. Answer questions a–c about the function \(y=(x-2)(x-4)\).
  1. What are the \(x\)-intercepts of the graph of \(y=(x-2)(x-4)\)?
    • \((2,0)\) and \((4,0)\)
    • \((0,2)\) and \((0,4)\)
    • \((-2,0)\) and \((-4,0)\)
    • \((0,-2)\) and \((0,-4)\)

ANSWER: \((2,0)\) and \((4,0)\)

  1. Is \((-1,3)\) a point on the graph?
    • Yes
    • No

ANSWER: No. Substituting -1 for \(x\) gives \((-1-2)(-1-4)\) or \(-3 \cdot -5\), which is 15, so \((-1,15)\) would be a point on the graph, not \((-1,3)\).

    1. Does the graph represent the equation \(y=(x-2)(x-4)\)?

      • Yes
      • No

ANSWER: No
